texts.text-8-3: Some information about the broad-snouted caiman...
texts.text-8-4: It's a kind of crocodile from the Alligatoridae family.
texts.text-8-5: Its common name is broad-snouted caiman and its scientific name is Caiman latirostris.
texts.text-8-6: It can exceed three meters in length.
texts.text-8-7: It builds its nest in some quiet lagoon. To do this, form a mound with materials found on site.
texts.text-8-9: The nest can have up to 1 meter in diameter and 60 centimeters in height.
texts.text-8-10: The females take care of the young on their own, protecting them from potential predators such as birds of prey.
texts.text-8-11: Its diet is exclusively carnivorous; it mainly consumes snails, other mollusks, and crustaceans.
texts.text-8-12: It captures reptiles and small mammals, such as rats, mice, and bats.
texts.text-8-13: It inhabits swampy and lacustrine regions of Bolivia, Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay, and Uruguay.
texts.text-8-14: In Uruguay, it can be found over the basin of the Merín Lagoon, from Rocha to Cerro Largo, in the northern part of the Negro River, in the Tacuarembó River and along the entire coast up to Paysandú.
texts.text-8-15: They call it overo because its skin has a coloring of diffuse spots, between deep green and pale gray.
texts.text-8-16: Thanks to the color of its skin, it can camouflage with the dense vegetation typical of its habitat.
texts.text-8-17: Its main natural enemies are the southern crested caracara, the crab hawk, and the jabiru.
texts.text-8-18: But above all, humans, who want to hunt it to make wallets and shoes with its skin.
texts.text-9-0: Many things are said about me…
texts.text-9-1:
Some Indigenous peoples of America believe that my teeth
                        have healing powers.
texts.text-9-2:
Supposedly, if they hang from the neck or an arm, they
                        avoid snake bites, and if they don't avoid them, the venom becomes harmless.
texts.text-9-3: They also believe that pressing and scraping one of my teeth over the snake bite, sucking on it, is an infallible remedy.
texts.text-9-4: Others say that my teeth are very powerful to overcome the air.
texts.text-9-6:
In popular medicine, it is believed that an air current can
                    penetrate the body and cause muscle pain.
texts.text-9-7:
If one of my teeth is passed over the painful area, it absorbs the
                    air and relieves the pain.
texts.text-9-8: Others speak of the power my sharp vertebrae have, saying that if warriors use them to make cuts on different parts of their bodies, they instill them with strength and courage.
texts.text-9-9:
The Guaraní believe that my origin dates back to a time when the
                        Earth would have collided with the Sun and a great fire ensued.
texts.text-9-10:
That day, the men who sank into the river to avoid burning
                        turned into crocodiles and capybaras.

texts.text-12-9: How is the rainforest different from the desert?
texts.text-12-10: And what about the prairie tundra?
texts.text-12-11: And what is the difference between a temperate forest and a tropical forest?
texts.text-12-12: What similarities do the prairie and the savanna have?
texts.text-12-13: Why do some living beings inhabit one region and not another?
texts.text-13-1:
Life on our planet depends on the energy from the sun, the
                        availability of water, and the existence of nutrients in the soil, among other factors.
texts.text-13-2: But not all regions of the world possess the same conditions.
texts.text-13-3:
In each region of the planet there are different climates,
                        landforms, and soil types that generate the environmental conditions for the development of life
                        in that place.
texts.text-13-4:
In each region lives a group of beings adapted to the place they
                        inhabit.
texts.text-13-5:
For example, in the desert, both plants and animals are adapted
                        to the scarce availability of water.
texts.text-13-6:
Living beings that inhabit a region also relate to each other,
                        for example, some are food for others.
texts.text-13-7:
Each of the regions where living beings interact with each other
                        and with the place where they live is called an ecosystem.
texts.text-13-8:
On Earth, we find similar ecosystems in places that are very
                        distant from each other.
texts.text-13-9:
For example, there are jungles and tropical forests in the
                        center of Africa, northern South America, and Southeast Asia.
texts.text-13-10: Ecosystems can be classified into different types called biomes.
texts.text-13-11: For example: jungles, deserts, forests or prairies.
texts.text-13-12: Biomes and the Action of Man
texts.text-13-13:
Human beings are part of the living beings that inhabit
                        biomes.
texts.text-13-14: To meet their needs, humans modify the natural environment.
texts.text-13-15:
For example, they cultivate fields, build buildings, bridges,
                        highways, among other transformations.
texts.text-13-16:
Specialists point out that currently there are no longer any
                        completely natural environments, that is, ones that have not been modified by human action.
texts.text-13-17:
The transformation of nature is essential for human life, but
                        it is often carried out without the necessary care, resulting in damage that can be
                        irreparable.
texts.text-13-19: The climate and topography are of great importance in the formation of biomes.
texts.text-13-20: For example, some mountain ranges with enormous interposed walls in the path of the humid winds coming from the ocean.
texts.text-13-21: When they collide with the mountain, these winds release their moisture on the slope facing the sea, while the other slope is arid.
texts.text-13-22: Likewise, height is a determining factor: in the mountains, biomes are distributed in zones according to altitude.
texts.text-14-0: Excessive deforestation, indiscriminate hunting of some species, intensive fishing (hake, for example), and land drilling for mining exploitation (oil, coal, and other minerals) are some examples of activities that can cause damage to the planet.
texts.text-14-1: Environmental specialists propose that human activities should be carried out taking into account the needs of future generations. This type of development is called sustainable development.
texts.text-14-2: The World Commission on Environment of the United Nations (UN) defines sustainable development as "development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs."
texts.text-14-5: They are also called tropical forests. They develop in areas with high temperatures and abundant rainfall during much of the year.
texts.text-14-6: They extend on both sides of the equator in Central America, South America, Africa, Asia, and Australia.
texts.text-14-7: The Amazon rainforest is the largest and coincides with the Amazon River basin. Its approximate area is 7,000,000 km².
texts.text-14-9: They have a large quantity and variety of vegetation: large, medium, and small trees, lianas, vines, ferns, shrubs, and herbaceous vegetation, distributed in layers (the tallest trees form a canopy, under which the other species live in a disordered and tangled manner).
texts.text-14-10: They also present a large quantity and variety of animals, for example, monkeys, reptiles, birds, insects, and predatory mammals.
texts.text-14-11: Economic activities are linked to the exploitation of forest and mining resources. Deforestation or the logging of species causes serious consequences, for example, loss of biodiversity, global climate changes, disappearance of animal and plant species, and loss of soils.
texts.text-15-1: They develop in areas with temperate and cold climates.
texts.text-15-2:
The trees in the forests are arranged in a single layer and are
                        very spaced apart, and they have a dormant period during the winter.
texts.text-15-3:
There is less variety of vegetables and animals than in the
                        jungle.
texts.text-15-4:
In temperate zones, forests are made up of deciduous trees and
                        shrubs, while those in colder regions consist of conifers, evergreen trees.
texts.text-15-5:
The wildlife of the forests is mainly made up of predators,
                        such as foxes, wolves, cougars, and lynxes.
texts.text-15-6:
In temperate forests, deforestation for wood use or for the
                        development of agriculture and livestock leads to the loss of animal and plant species.
texts.text-15-7:
The taiga is a forest characteristic of the cold climates of
                        the northern hemisphere; it develops in Canada and Siberia.
texts.text-15-8:
The characteristic species are firs, pines, larches, and
                        birches.
texts.text-15-9:
Its fauna is composed of animals that withstand the cold:
                        moose, bison, wolves, bears, lynxes, squirrels, marmots, beavers, and deer; many of them
                        hibernate.
texts.text-15-11: They develop in areas with a temperate and humid climate.
texts.text-15-12: They lack almost completely trees and have a large amount of soft and even grasses.
texts.text-15-13: They are ideal for the development of agricultural activities, such as cereal and oilseed crops, and livestock activities, for example, cattle breeding.

texts.text-26-1:
The Kenyan biologist Wangari Maathai wanted to combat the
                            poverty that deforestation was causing in her country.
texts.text-26-2:
To do this, he began
                            planting trees and invited others to imitate the initiative.
texts.text-26-3:
Thus, with its Green Belt project, it promoted the planting of
                        more than 47 million trees in Africa.
texts.text-26-4:
In 2004, he received the Nobel Peace Prize for his advocacy of
                        sustainable development and the environment.
texts.text-26-7:
He denounced the damage of indiscriminate logging and managed
                            to mobilize many people who joined his cause.
texts.text-26-8:
The landowners harmed by his struggle killed him, but he
                            raised environmental awareness in Brazil, America, and the entire world.
texts.text-26-10:
Jacques-Yves Cousteau was a French explorer who traveled the
                        world researching marine biomes.
texts.text-26-11:
He filmed underwater documentaries and spread knowledge about
                        the different forms of life that inhabit the sea.
texts.text-26-12:
He organized campaigns to stop the dumping of radioactive
                        waste into the sea and, with the support of many people, succeeded more than once.
texts.text-26-14: The Inuit, inhabitants of the Arctic, know the magnificent biodiversity of the area they inhabit and are direct witnesses to the environmental damage in the region.
texts.text-26-15: Caroline Cannon, a member of this community, has faced powerful companies interested in the oil wealth of the Arctic region for years.

texts.text-31-6: Forests provide a habitat for a wide variety of plants and animals and fulfill many other functions that affect humans.
texts.text-31-7: Along with others, these large plant communities are responsible, for example, for the production of oxygen during photosynthesis.
texts.text-31-8: Photosynthesis is the chemical process by which green leaves and stems use sunlight and carbon dioxide to produce sugars that provide energy to the tree.
texts.text-31-9: During the process, the foliage of the trees releases oxygen, a necessary element for breathing.
texts.text-31-10: Forests also prevent erosion, that is, the wear of the soil caused by wind and rain.
texts.text-31-11: In bare areas, with little or no vegetation, rain can wash the soil into rivers and streams, causing landslides and floods.
texts.text-31-12: However, in densely wooded areas, the roots of the trees and plants hold the soil and slow down these processes.
texts.text-31-13: In wooded areas, the canopy of leaves (the tree canopies) intercepts and gradually redistributes rainwater.
texts.text-31-14: One part of the precipitation then flows through the bark of the trunks and the rest runs off through the branches and foliage.
texts.text-31-15: That slower and less uniform distribution of rain contributes to the soil not being washed away immediately.
texts.text-31-16: In this way, the possibility of flooding and erosion is reduced.
texts.text-31-17:
Forests can also increase the land's capacity to retain and store
                    water reserves.
texts.text-31-18:
The leaf vault is especially efficient at capturing water from fog
                    (condensed water vapor).
texts.text-31-19:
The water captured in the tree canopies is then distributed to the
                    vegetation and soil as precipitation.
texts.text-31-20:
The water stored in the roots, trunks, stems, foliage, and soil of the
                    forest land allows forests to maintain a constant flow of moisture during times of drought.

texts.text-34-2: Study manuals help us to know and understand the subjects we study in school.
texts.text-34-3:
They are reliable sources of information, just like dictionaries, encyclopedias, or some
                        magazines and blogs.
texts.text-34-4: Good manuals make complex topics easy to understand.
texts.text-34-5: Because they are intended for students, the manuals organize information carefully and convey it clearly.

On its pages you can find texts, illustrations, maps, and graphs. In addition, the manuals propose
                activities and experiments to learn.

texts.text-35-1:
Write
                    a list of environmental problems that inhabitants of large cities have to face daily.
texts.text-35-3:
Read
                    this article and underline the environmental problems it mentions.
texts.text-35-4:
Complete
                    the list in the notebook with the new information provided by the article.
texts.text-35-6:
Large cities often have various problems caused by the management of a limited
                    territory where millions of people live.
texts.text-35-7: Air pollution is a serious problem in some cities.
texts.text-35-8: It is caused by the emission of gases from vehicle transit and industries.
texts.text-35-9:
Smog is the haze that remains in the city, causing health problems and creating an
                    urban microclimate characterized by increased temperature.
texts.text-35-10: Intense traffic is also a source of noise pollution.
texts.text-35-11:
The permanent movement of the population within the city and between it and
                    neighboring cities creates transportation problems.
texts.text-35-12:
Many times, transportation systems are not sufficient, which causes congestion and
                    chaos during peak hours.
texts.text-35-13: A large city consumes significant volumes of water, food, and energy.
texts.text-35-14:
Similarly, economic activities and households generate thousands of tons of garbage
                    every day, which the city's public services must collect, treat, and deposit at final disposal
                    sites.
texts.text-35-15:
The same happens with sewage, which must be channeled through sanitation systems,
                    which do not always exist or are not sufficient.

Many centuries ago, travelers and explorers wrote descriptions of
                nature, although they were not as accurate as those of today's science.
texts.text-39-2: After an exploratory trip through the Caribbean,
texts.text-39-3: Melchor de Barros claimed to have seen a region with land so good that giant trees grew there.
texts.text-39-4: They were so tall that it was impossible to reach their tops by shooting arrows.
texts.text-39-5: and it took six men holding hands to encircle their gigantic trunks.
texts.text-39-7:
This is how the English navigator Walter Raleigh described the inhabitants of
                        America:
texts.text-39-8:
men who have heads lower than their shoulders, and others with feet so large
                        that they serve as a parasol,
texts.text-39-9:
some with three rows of teeth in each jaw, body of a bear, lion's legs, and
                        scorpion's tail.

texts.sectioneli5-0-0: This is a notebook for fifth-grade children to learn to read and write. There is a space to put your name, your school, your class, and the year. There is also a fun character that looks like a crocodile dressed in red, probably to make it more interesting and friendly. This notebook is part of early and primary education in the educational system of Uruguay.
texts.sectioneli5-2-0: This is a special notebook that helps fifth-grade children learn to read and write better. It is like a tool or book to practice these important skills while they are in elementary school.
texts.sectioneli5-6-0: The "Index" is like a map of the book that tells us what topics are there and on which page to find them. For example, there are sections that explain about the biomes and others that tell stories like "La taberna del loro en el hombro". This way we know where each topic is in the book and we can go directly to it without getting lost.
texts.sectioneli5-7-0: Hello, I am Yacaré. I am here to accompany you while you read and write. Let's learn together in a fun way.
texts.sectioneli5-7-1: When you see this friendly crocodile with a pencil, it's a sign that it's time to write. He wants you to take your pencil too and write something. Let's write together!
texts.sectioneli5-7-2: When you see this friendly crocodile with a book, it's an invitation for you to read as well. It is telling you that it's a good time to enjoy a story together.
texts.sectioneli5-7-3: When you see Yacaré in a circle with friends, it's time to listen to an interesting story. This means it's a good time to sit together and enjoy a fun reading.
texts.sectioneli5-8-0: In the images, we see three friends: a jaguar, an owl, and a crocodile. The crocodile is introducing the other two and mentions that they are in different school grades. It's as if they are adventure companions in a story, with one being with you in fourth grade and the other in sixth. It's a fun way to get to know these characters from a story or book.
texts.sectioneli5-8-1:
The broad-snouted caiman is a type of crocodile that lives in countries such as Bolivia, Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay, and Uruguay. It is like a crocodile that can be as long as a small car. It likes to live in calm lagoons and builds its home with things it finds near the water.

This crocodile eats meat, such as snails and mice. It takes care of its babies very carefully to protect them from other animals that want to eat them. Its skin has green and gray spots that help it hide among the plants.

Its enemies are some animals and humans, who sometimes want its skin to make bags and shoes. The broad-snouted caiman is very good at hiding in its home and in the water, so it's very special how it camouflages with its surroundings.
texts.sectioneli5-9-0: Some people in America thought that the teeth of certain animals were very special. They believed that if you wore these teeth as a necklace or bracelet, they would protect you from snake bites. And if a snake bit you, the venom would not harm you. In the images, you can see people wearing those teeth as necklaces because that made them feel safer.
texts.sectioneli5-9-1: In some tales, it is believed that if someone is bitten by a snake, they can use a special tooth and rub it on the bite. This is supposed to help draw out the poison and heal the wound. It's like having a magical "supertoth" to heal immediately.
texts.sectioneli5-9-2: In some stories, there is a magical belief that a special tooth can help cure pain. It is said that if you pass this tooth over a sore muscle, like on the back, the tooth "sucks out" or "absorbs" the bad air that causes the pain, and thus you feel better. It is as if the tooth has a secret power to calm the body.
texts.sectioneli5-9-3: Some people tell stories about how warriors used special sharp bones. These bones, according to the stories, were used to make small cuts on their own bodies, and by doing this, the warriors felt that they had more strength and courage. It's a bit like when you put on a superhero's cape and feel like you can fly. They are ancient beliefs about objects that give you special powers.
texts.sectioneli5-9-4: The Guarani have a magical story about how certain animals were born. They say that there was a day when Earth collided with the Sun and everything was set ablaze. To avoid getting burned, some men submerged themselves in the river. In doing so, they transformed into yacarés and capybaras, which are like crocodiles and large rodents! This is an ancient legend that explains the origin of these animals.
texts.sectioneli5-9-5: Here you are asked to look for interesting facts about the yacaré, which is a type of crocodile. Then, you should write what you find and make a drawing of the yacaré. It's like a small fun research project to learn more about this animal.
texts.sectioneli5-10-0: In this activity, you have to draw or paste a picture of one of your friends in the large box in the center. Then, complete the other boxes with information about your friend. Like their name, what they like to do, who they play with, how their hair and eyes are, what they like or dislike when they are sad or happy. In this way, we can get to know your friends better and learn more about them.
texts.sectioneli5-10-1: To do this activity, draw your friend in the center box or put a picture of them. Then, think about things about your friend like their name, how their friends call them, what they like to play, and what makes them happy or sad. Complete each box with that information. At the end, write a bit about your friend using all the information you noted. That way, you'll have a written portrait of your best friend.
texts.sectioneli5-12-0: There are many types of places in nature, such as a rainforest that has many trees and is very green, or a desert that is dry with sand. Each place is different and has its own climate and plants. Maps and drawings help to see what these places look like. It is good to know this to understand why some animals and plants live in certain places and not in others.
texts.sectioneli5-12-1:
The Earth has different places where animals and plants live, called ecosystems. Let's see how some of them compare.

- **Tropical rainforest and desert**: The tropical rainforest is very humid and rains a lot, so it has many trees and animals. The desert, on the other hand, is very dry and has little water, so only some animals and plants can live there.

- **Tundra and prairie**: The tundra is very cold and has frozen soil, with few plants. The prairie is warmer and has tall grass and flowers, but not many trees.

- **Temperate forest and tropical forest**: The temperate forest has seasons and trees that change color. The tropical forest is always green and warm, with a lot of rain.

- **Prairie and savanna**: Both have grass, but the savanna also has some trees and is hot. The prairie has more seasons and can be cooler.

Animals and plants live in a specific place because they find the climate and food they need to survive there.
texts.sectioneli5-13-0:
Biomes are places on Earth where plants and animals have adapted to live there. Life depends on the sun, water, and nutrients from the soil, but not all places are the same.

For example, in deserts, plants and animals have learned to live with little water. Regions where living beings interact with each other and their environment are called ecosystems. These ecosystems can be like jungles, deserts, forests, or grasslands.

On Earth, we find similar ecosystems in distant places, such as the jungles of South America, Africa, and Asia. The images show different environments, like ice, deserts, and jungles, to help you imagine what these places are like.
texts.sectioneli5-13-1: Humans live in different places around the world called biomes, such as forests or deserts. To make their lives more comfortable, humans change the world around them, like when they create fields for farming or build roads. But sometimes, they are not careful with nature and cause damage that cannot be repaired. It's important to make changes without harming the natural world.
texts.sectioneli5-13-2: Biomes are like large natural houses where plants and animals live. Mountains are important for biomes because they change the climate. When the wind full of sea water hits a mountain, it rains on that side. But on the other side, it can be dry like a desert. Also, the height of the mountains matters because it changes which plants and animals can live there.
texts.sectioneli5-14-0: When we cut down many trees or overfish, we can harm our planet. That's why experts say we should take care of the Earth in a way that also thinks about the children of the future. This is called 'sustainable development'. It means using what we need now without forgetting that the children of the future will also need those things.
texts.sectioneli5-14-1:
Rainforests, also called tropical forests, are places in the world where it is very hot and there is a lot of rain almost all year round. They are found in places near the equator, such as South America, Africa, and Asia.

In the rainforests, there are many different types of plants and animals, such as large and small trees, vines, monkeys, birds, and many others. The Amazon rainforest is the largest of all.

Rainforests are important, but when people cut down many trees or search for minerals without care, they can damage the environment. This means that some animals may disappear and the Earth's climate can change.
texts.sectioneli5-15-0:
Forests are places full of trees. There are forests in places with temperate climates (not very hot or very cold) and in cold places.

In these forests, the trees are spaced apart and rest in winter. There are fewer plants and animals than in the jungle. Trees in temperate climates lose their leaves (as in autumn), whereas in colder climates there are trees like pines that always have leaves.

In the forests, animals like foxes and wolves live and hunt for food. There are large forests in Canada and Siberia, where animals that withstand the cold, such as bears and lynxes, live, and many hibernate (sleep all winter). The image shows a forest in Chile with many pines.
texts.sectioneli5-15-1: The prairies are like large open fields where lots of soft, even grass grows. In these places, there are almost no trees. They are perfect for planting things like cereals and for having animals like cows. The photo shows a prairie in Uruguay, which is ideal for these activities.
texts.sectioneli5-16-0: When we read a text, we can see that it has a large title and some smaller subtitles. The word that is repeated the most among them tells us what the whole text is about, that is, what the topic is. It's like discovering the clue that shows us what is going to be discussed in the story or book! Sometimes, a friendly character also helps us remember this. So, by filling in the outline, we can better understand the content.
texts.sectioneli5-16-1: Biomes are like types of landscapes that depend on climate and landforms. Imagine the wind bringing water from the sea, but if it encounters a mountain, it drops the water on one side and the other side remains dry. Also, the height of the mountain causes plants and animals to live on different levels, like in a building.
texts.sectioneli5-16-2: Let's find the main theme of a text. Think about which word or idea repeats a lot, because it gives you a clue about the topic. Then, look for a sentence that says the most important thing about the text. Just like when a cartoon character helps you solve a mystery, you're looking for clues in the text to figure out what it's about.
texts.sectioneli5-18-0:
This activity is about learning about different types of landscapes in the world, called biomes. There are two images, and you must decide which one best explains how these biomes work.

- In the first image, we see how some places have forests with a lot of rain and others have dry deserts. It's like seeing which places are wet or dry.

- The other image shows a mountain, and you can see different parts of it, like the valley and the summit, where different things happen, like the climate or the type of plants that grow.

The task is to use these clues to place 'wet slope' or 'dry slope' labels in the correct place on the images.
texts.sectioneli5-18-1: You have two landscape drawings. One shows a mountain with rain and dry air, and the other shows a mountain with various parts like the summit and the valley. Your task is to choose which one explains the different environments of the world better. Then, think about your reasons: Why did you choose that image? Or why did you discard the other one? This helps you practice how to think and explain your ideas about places in nature.
texts.sectioneli5-19-0: Here you have to decide if some questions can be answered after reading about 'Biomes'. You have questions like how life originated or where jungles are. If you think they can be answered with the reading, you write 'yes'. If not, you write 'no'. It's a way to practice what you understand after reading a text.
texts.sectioneli5-19-1: Imagine you have a book that talks about 'Types of Biomes', that is, the different places like forests and deserts on earth. Your task is to think of three questions that you can answer after reading about the biomes. Then, you have to share these questions with your classmates so that everyone can learn and think together about what they read.
texts.sectioneli5-19-2: You need to take two questions that your friends have written and write the answers yourself. It's like a game where you read what they ask and think of the best answer to those questions. It's a fun way to learn together!
texts.sectioneli5-19-3: Sometimes, when you read something and you're not sure if you understand it, it's good to read it again. This helps to better understand the subject, especially in things like Social Sciences.
texts.sectioneli5-19-4: Did you know that it's normal not to understand something at first? Sometimes, we need to read something several times to understand it well. It's like trying to put together a puzzle! Reading over and over helps you find the right piece. So don't worry, just keep trying.
texts.sectioneli5-20-0:
In this exercise, we are going to learn about different "biomes," which are large areas of the Earth with their own plants, animals, and climate.

There is a table we need to complete about three types of biomes: rainforests, forests, and grasslands.
- **Rainforests:** We need to write about their climate, the plants and animals that live there, and what activities people do in that place.
- **Forests:** Here, you need to include what type of climate they have, such as temperate climates, and details about the vegetation and fauna.
- **Grasslands:** Add information about their climate and the rest.

A fun crocodile character also reminds us that we can look in the previous text to find the information and fill it in the table. It's like a data search game about our world!
texts.sectioneli5-20-1:
To understand how the different biomes or natural places in the world are, you have to focus on some important things. For example, the temperature, whether it is hot or cold, and the type of soil, which is how the earth is—whether there is more sand or it is rockier. 

When filling out this chart, you use those details to identify what makes each type of biome special, such as jungles, forests, or grasslands. It's like a game to know why each place is unique and different!
texts.sectioneli5-21-0:
These notes help you learn about the prairies of Uruguay. 

1. **Vegetation**: The plants that grow there are like grasses and shrubs.

2. **Economic activities**: Much of Uruguay is prairie, so people tend animals and grow plants there as their main job.

3. **Climate**: It is cool, around 15 degrees, and it rains a lot between 500 and 1000 millimeters.

It is an important place for nature and work in Uruguay!
texts.sectioneli5-21-1: Remember the text about prairies and find three places where you can add new information. Use the notes you have related to vegetation, economic activities, and climate to make the text more complete. Simply find the right place and add each note where it corresponds.
texts.sectioneli5-21-2: Prairies are large fields that have a temperate and humid climate, which means it is neither too hot nor too cold and it rains sufficiently. In the prairies, there are almost no trees, but many soft and flat grasses grow. These grasses are perfect for planting things like grains, which are small seeds we can eat, and also for raising cattle, which provide us with milk and meat. In Uruguay, these prairies are very important because they cover much of the land and greatly assist in working the land and caring for animals.
texts.sectioneli5-21-3:
Here is a small task to write about the prairies of Uruguay. We will use three notebooks that have important notes:

1. **Vegetation**: In the prairie, there are plants like grasses and shrubs, for example, chirca.
2. **Economic activities**: In Uruguay, the prairie occupies 80% of the country. Farming and livestock activities are very important here.
3. **Climate**: The prairies have a climate with temperatures of 15°C and it rains between 500 and 1000 mm.

Before writing, make sure to put all this data together and use punctuation to make everything clear. Write as if you are telling a story about the prairies of Uruguay!
texts.sectioneli5-22-0: When we talk about a 'biome', it's like saying there's a neighborhood where many little animals and plants live together. Here, the climate (whether it's cold or hot) and the terrain (such as mountains or flat ground) are important. So a biome is a special community where everyone helps each other out and lives according to the local rules, like in the jungle or the desert.
texts.sectioneli5-22-1:
Today we are going to learn some interesting words about nature:

- **Deciduous foliage**: This means that some trees have leaves that fall off when it gets cold, like in the fall.

- **Predators**: In the forests, there are animals that hunt others to eat, like wolves.

- **Oilseeds**: These are plants, like the sunflower, that are cultivated because their seeds contain oils that we can use.
texts.sectioneli5-23-0: People are part of the place where they live and to do the things they need, such as growing food or building houses, they change nature. These changes can sometimes harm the environment, although they are important for our lives. We need to be careful about how we affect the planet to avoid damaging it too much.
texts.sectioneli5-23-1: People do some things that can harm nature. For example, when they cut down many trees, it is called deforestation, and that's not good because it causes animals to lose their homes. Also, if we damage the soil where plants grow, it is called soil loss. This can make the plants and animals living there disappear, and that is a loss of biodiversity. It is important to take care of the planet so that all living beings are happy and healthy!
texts.sectioneli5-24-0:
In America, there are different types of large areas called biomes, and two of them are the savannah and the desert.

The **savannah** has a tropical climate and two types of seasons: a dry one and another with a lot of rain. Many animals like jaguars and deer live here, and agriculture and cattle farming are done in the savannah.

The **desert** is a very dry and hot place, with very little rain. Here special plants called xerophytes grow, like cacti, which are good for living with little water. In the desert, some people search for minerals in the soil.

A little drawing of a crocodile with a pencil reminds you to note down these important things to learn about the biomes.
texts.sectioneli5-24-1:
Let's talk about places in America called biomes. Two examples are the savanna and the desert. The savanna is a place with a warm climate where there are rainy and dry seasons. Animals like jaguars and deer live there, and people engage in agriculture and livestock farming.

The desert is very hot and it rains very little, which is why plants and animals must adapt. 'Xerophytic' is a word for plants that live with little water, like cacti. These plants know how to survive in drought. The book in the image could teach us more about these topics.
texts.sectioneli5-25-0: In this game, you have to match words that go together, like pieces of a puzzle. For example, 'mountain' and 'slope' are related because slopes are parts of mountains. It's like finding things that go well together in nature, like 'trees' that go with 'forests'. Have fun finding these pairs! 🌳🏞️
texts.sectioneli5-25-1: You should think of a word that connects or relates to the two words already given. For example, if you have "liquid" and "gaseous," you are thinking about "states of water." So, look for a word that makes sense with those that are there. This helps to learn new words and how they relate to each other.
texts.sectioneli5-26-0: Wangari Maathai was a woman from Kenya who wanted to help her country because there were fewer trees. She started planting many trees and encouraged everyone to do the same. Her project, called Green Belt, helped plant 47 million trees in Africa. That's a lot of trees! For all her work to care for the planet, she won a very important award in 2004, called the Nobel Peace Prize.
texts.sectioneli5-26-1: Chico Mendes was a person who worked collecting rubber from trees in Brazil. He wanted to take care of the forest and didn't want it to be cut down uncontrollably. He spoke with many people to help protect the forest. Some people who disagreed with him hurt him, but Chico managed to get more people in Brazil and around the world to care about protecting the environment.
texts.sectioneli5-26-2: Jacques-Yves Cousteau was an explorer who loved the ocean. He traveled all over the world to learn about the animals and plants that live in the sea. He made films to show people how amazing the ocean floor is. He also helped stop dangerous things from being dumped in the sea, campaigning with the help of many people.
texts.sectioneli5-26-3: The Inuit are people who live in a very cold place called the Arctic. There are many special animals and plants there. Caroline Cannon is part of their group and has been trying to protect her home. There are large companies that want to extract oil from their land, but that can harm the environment. She works with scientists to ensure this does not happen.
texts.sectioneli5-27-0: This poster talks about Arbor Day. It says that trees are very important because they help us breathe by creating oxygen, and they also help the planet. There is a very special message telling us to plant a tree to help. The poster has a short and catchy phrase: 'you are the air that I breathe', which makes us think about how important trees are to us.
texts.sectioneli5-27-1:
In this exercise, we are looking at a poster that has different parts. Each part does something important:

1. One part tells people why trees are good for the environment. This is to explain.
2. Another part is designed to make people want to plant trees. This is to invite.
3. There is also a part that provides information about who organizes the campaign. This is to inform.
4. Finally, the slogan, which is a short and memorable phrase, helps us remember the idea that trees are important.

The slogan here, 'You are the air I breathe,' makes us think about how valuable trees are.
texts.sectioneli5-28-0: In this activity, we are learning how verbs change depending on who is doing the action. For example, if I am speaking about myself, I use 'I'. If I am speaking about other people, I use 'they'. The task is to match the correct verbs (like 'add' and 'generate') with the correct pronouns (like 'I', 'you', 'he'). It's a game to better understand how we talk about different people in Spanish!
texts.sectioneli5-28-1: This activity is like a game where we fill in the blanks with the correct verbs for each person. In the story, there are words that indicate who is speaking or doing something, such as 'I', 'you', 'we', and 'they'. These are personal pronouns. For example, when someone says 'I', we talk about oneself. You will need to use the correct form of the verb for each pronoun. Have fun completing what each character is doing in the image, like bringing water or taking care of something.
texts.sectioneli5-28-2: In this exercise, we look for words that change when we talk about different people, such as "I," "we," or "they." These words are verbs, like "to breathe" or "to sum." Imagine that "to breathe" is like "I breathe" when I talk about myself. It's like a game of finding which words go with each person who speaks.
texts.sectioneli5-28-3: Here, we are playing with verbs, which are action words like run, jump, or paint. We have to find other verbs, like 'generan', and write their simple form, called the infinitive, which in this case is 'generate'. Try to think of more verbs and write their infinitives, like 'eat' or 'play'. It's like finding the simple name of the action.
texts.sectioneli5-28-4:
Pronouns are words we use to talk about people without saying their names. In Spanish, there are pronouns for one or more than one. 

- **If it's one (singular):**
  - I: when you talk about yourself.
  - You: when you talk to one person.
  - He/She: when you talk about a boy or a girl.

- **If it's more than one (plural):**
  - We: when you talk about yourself and other people.
  - You (plural): when you talk to several people.
  - They: when you talk about more than one boy or girl.

Drawings help us remember how these words are used. This way, stories and conversations in Spanish are better understood.
texts.sectioneli5-29-0: When we use words like "plant a tree" or "join," we are telling someone to do something directly. It's like when mom or dad says "Clean your room!" This is about planting trees, which is important for the air we breathe. The little drawings help us remember that it's a good idea to be part of the solution, taking care of the planet.
texts.sectioneli5-29-1: This guide teaches you how to plant a tree using words that are like commands. First, 'loosen' the soil. Then, 'open' a hole for the roots. 'Take' the tree from the bottom and 'place' it in the hole. 'Cover' the roots with soil, not too tight. If the soil is poor, 'add' fertilizer. Finally, 'protect' the tree from animals. This way, we take care of the trees and help them grow.
texts.sectioneli5-30-0:
Here we have a crossword puzzle that you can solve with clues about science. Think of words that describe things like:

1. A science about life, such as plants and animals.
2. An organism that is very small, like a bacterium.
3. A type of fuel made from plants or organic waste.
4. Different types of places with many plants, like jungles or deserts.
5. The complete history of a person.

See what these words have in common and what they mean. It's a fun exercise to learn how to use words well!
texts.sectioneli5-30-1:
Here you have a game to connect words with pictures. 
1. "Twin-engine" is the plane that has two engines, that's why it's called that.
2. "Library bus" is like a bus full of books, suitable for the picture of the bus.
3. "Bilingual" is for the person who says "Hello" and "Bonjour", showing that they speak two languages.
4. "Library" is the piece of furniture full of books.
5. "Bicolor" is related to the two-colored flag.
6. "Bibliomania" is about the person who is reading intently. 
This game helps learn new words while we look at fun pictures.
texts.sectioneli5-30-2: In Spanish, some words have bits called 'compositional elements', like 'bi-' and 'biblio-'. These bits have their own meaning. When we combine them with other bits, they create new words. For example, 'biblio-' means something related to books, like in 'biblioteca'. And 'bi-' can mean two, as in 'bilingual', which refers to speaking two languages. These bits always start with the letter 'b'.
texts.sectioneli5-30-3: The activity is about understanding what some parts of words mean. For example, 'bi-' means two, so any word with 'bi-' is related to the number two. And 'biblio-' is related to books or libraries. Learning these bits helps you understand longer words.
texts.sectioneli5-31-0:
Forests are like big homes for many animals and plants. They do important things such as:

- **Photosynthesis:** Trees take sunlight and air to make their own food and give us oxygen to breathe.

- **Rain interception:** The leaves of the trees catch rain and distribute it gradually, like a watering can, so the ground doesn't flood.

- **Provide a home:** Forests are where many animals, like deer, live happily.

- **Store water:** The roots of the trees store water in the soil, which helps during times of drought.

- **Prevent erosion:** The roots also hold the soil in place so it is not carried away by wind or water.
texts.sectioneli5-31-1: Forests are places where many animals and plants live. They do very important things for us. For example, trees use sunlight to make their food through a process called photosynthesis. During this process, trees take in air that we cannot breathe (carbon dioxide) and transform it into air that we can breathe (oxygen). In this way, they help us have clean air to breathe.
texts.sectioneli5-31-2: Imagine the ground is like a carpet of sand. When it rains or is windy, that sand can move and create disorder in the house. That happens in nature, but forests help keep everything in place. The roots of the trees are like fingers that firmly grip the ground so that it doesn't blow away or get washed away by water. Thus, the trees help prevent landslides and floods.
texts.sectioneli5-31-3: In the forests, the leaves of the trees help with the rain. When it rains, the leaves catch some of the water and let it fall gradually. Additionally, some water runs down the trunks, and the rest flows over the branches and leaves. This helps prevent the water from quickly removing the soil, avoiding large puddles and preventing the soil from wearing away or breaking easily.
texts.sectioneli5-31-4: Forests help retain water. The leaves of trees are very good at trapping water from fog. Then, this water spreads through the plants and soil. All of this helps the forest maintain its moisture, even when it does not rain much.
texts.sectioneli5-32-0:
Before making a summary, we first need to read an article about what forests do. 

Then, we number the paragraphs and look for important words that appear in an image to connect each part of the text. 

For example, there are words like photosynthesis and habitat that tell us what that part of the text is about. This way we can complete the chart and better understand how forests are important.
texts.sectioneli5-32-1: In this activity, we are going to learn how forests help the environment. Think of trees as big umbrellas. When it rains, the tree canopies collect and scatter the water, which helps keep the soil healthy and strong. Additionally, forests are like homes for many animals, and they store water like a sponge. They also prevent the land from slipping, avoiding erosion. We focus on each of these functions and write about why they are important.
texts.sectioneli5-33-0: Here is a game where you must match things that happen with their causes. For example, wind and rain cause fewer problems to the soil in forests because tree roots help keep the ground firm. Also, animals live well in forests because they have a home there, and trees, by taking in sunlight, produce clean air that we breathe. Forests are important for these reasons and more.
texts.sectioneli5-33-1:
To finish the summary on why forests are important, think about how they help the Earth. Forests have many types of animals and plants, which we call biodiversity. They help the planet by doing things like producing oxygen and holding the soil with their roots.

When you write the summary, use connectors like 'additionally' and 'on the other hand' to link your ideas. For example, you can say: 'On one hand, forests give us oxygen; on the other hand, they help prevent soil erosion.' This makes your ideas connect in a clear and orderly way.
texts.sectioneli5-34-0: A study manual is like a special book that helps us learn and understand things at school. It is reliable, like a dictionary or a magazine. In the illustration, we see teachers and students working together in the library, utilizing these books to learn in a fun and safe manner.
texts.sectioneli5-34-1: Study manuals are like magical books that help to understand difficult topics. They organize all the information in an orderly and clear way so that students can understand it easily. In this way, learning becomes simpler and more enjoyable.
texts.sectioneli5-34-2: Study manuals are like special books that contain a lot of information to help us learn new things. Inside, you can find words, drawings, maps, and graphs. They also contain activities and experiments that are like games for learning. All the information is specifically designed to help students better understand the topics.
texts.sectioneli5-34-3: In science books, there is a character named Caiman latirostris, but his friends prefer to call him Yacaré. This is because sometimes scientific names are difficult, so we use easier nicknames. Additionally, study manuals are books that help students learn about many subjects clearly and reliably.
texts.sectioneli5-35-0: In this activity, we are going to make a list of environmental problems that people face in large cities every day. An example is the increase in temperature. By reading the article, we highlight those problems and then write them down to better understand what happens in the cities.
texts.sectioneli5-35-1:
Big cities have many problems due to the people who live there. One of the problems is air pollution. This happens because cars and factories release gases that dirty the air, creating smog, which is like a dirty cloud that can make us feel sick and heats the city more.

There is also a lot of noise due to traffic. When many people are moving all the time and there aren't enough buses or trains, traffic jams and chaos are formed. Additionally, cities use a lot of water, food, and energy, and produce a lot of trash. All this trash must be collected and treated, but sometimes it can't be done properly because there aren't enough places or systems to process it.

The same goes for dirty water, which needs to be carried through special pipes, but there aren't always enough. So, in big cities, they need to manage many things so that everything works well without harming the environment.
texts.sectioneli5-36-0: The trees in the city do many good things. They protect from the strong sun and rain as if they were umbrellas. They also trap dirt and smoke from the air, making the air cleaner. Trees are like homes for many little animals and help reduce noise. They even make the streets look nicer and improve our lives. Each tree helps, as if it takes the smoke from 100 cars every day. It's great to have trees around!
texts.sectioneli5-36-1: When we plant trees, they help make cities less hot. This is because trees provide shade and cool the air. So, when it’s really hot, trees help us feel cooler. They are like giant umbrellas that also clean the air and make life better for everyone, including the animals that live in them!
texts.sectioneli5-36-2: Planting trees in the city helps a lot. Trees clean the air by absorbing carbon dioxide and releasing pure oxygen. They also make the city more beautiful and reduce noise. They provide protection from the sun and rain, and give a home to animals. Additionally, trees trap dust and smoke, making the air cleaner. They are like superheroes for nature!
texts.sectioneli5-36-3: Planting trees in the city helps a lot. Trees make the air cleaner, block noise, and provide us with shade from the sun. They also serve as homes for small animals and make places look prettier. Planting trees is good for all of us because it makes life in the city better.
texts.sectioneli5-37-0: Cities grow a lot because many people need to live together near schools, hospitals, and jobs. But this also brings problems like dirtiness and lack of enough clean air. Trees in cities are super important because they help make the air cleaner and provide more shade. The text asks you to write an article explaining why these trees are a good solution for the problems of the cities.
texts.sectioneli5-38-0:
When you write an article, it is important to review it to ensure it has everything needed. Here is a list of questions to help you: 

1. Do you talk about cities and environmental problems?
2. Do you clearly explain what environmental problems people face in big cities?
3. Do you mention all the problems from your previous list?
4. Do you say why air pollution is serious?
5. Do you explain noise pollution?
6. Do you describe what happens with dirty water and garbage?

The image shows two children thinking and writing, which means they are carefully reviewing their work, just as you should do.
texts.sectioneli5-38-1: Here we are reviewing a paper that you wrote. The question is whether you have talked about how planting trees helps clean the city. We also want to know if you mentioned the benefits of having many trees in the city. For example, trees can help make the air cleaner. In the drawing, you see two children reviewing their writings with pencils and books, just like you when you review your homework.
texts.sectioneli5-38-2: Here are some tips for reviewing what you write, like a funny crocodile with its book would. First, check if you start your sentences with capital letters and correctly use punctuation marks like periods and commas. Second, make sure you don't repeat the same words too many times. If you do, change some for similar ones. Third, use beautiful words from books, not the ones we use every day. And don't forget to use words that connect ideas so that your text is well understood. It's like making a chain of words that are understood together.
texts.sectioneli5-39-0: Many years ago, some travelers and explorers wrote about what they found. But their descriptions were not as precise as those made by science today. Sometimes the trees seemed enormous, or they said that people had strange characteristics. It was like reading fantastic tales! Nowadays, we know that not everything was true.
texts.sectioneli5-39-1: A long time ago, an explorer named Melchor de Barros said that he saw a place with trees so big that you couldn't see their tops even if you shot arrows. They were so enormous that you needed six people holding hands to surround a tree! The drawings in the book show plants that look very large and astonishing.
texts.sectioneli5-39-2: A long time ago, when explorers traveled through new lands, they sometimes told very exaggerated stories. For example, Walter Raleigh spoke of people in America who had features like large feet they used to shade themselves from the sun and bodies mixed with animals like bears and lions. Gigantic creatures were also drawn, like the one seen next to a ship in the drawing. All this shows how they were more tales than reality.
texts.sectioneli5-39-3: When Christopher Columbus first traveled to America, he saw the nature and wrote that the sea was as calm as a river and that the air was the best in the world. He also said that the song of the little birds was so beautiful that no one would want to leave from there, and that there were so many parrots that they almost covered the sun. In those times, explorers usually told wonderful things about the places they visited.
texts.sectioneli5-39-4: A long time ago, some travelers told incredible stories about America. They talked about giant trees, people with lion's feet, and perfect rivers. These descriptions seem like fantasy tales. The text makes us wonder: can we believe everything these travelers said?

texts.easyread-text-24-24:
Biomes are big places on Earth with similar weather, plants, and animals. Examples are forests, deserts, and oceans.

Biomes can be hot or cold, wet or dry, and they help support different kinds of life. They are important for our planet.
texts.easyread-text-24-25: Xerophytic plants are plants that can live in dry places like deserts. They store water to survive.
texts.easyread-text-24-26: A xerófila plant is a plant that can live with very little water.
texts.easyread-text-24-27: A special plant or mushroom that can live with very little water and can stay alive when there is no rain.
